<span>/</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>  </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">thumbcaption</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">magnify</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Encoded_letter_of_Gabriel_Luetz_d_Aramon_after_1546_with_partial_deciphering.jpg">/wiki/File:Encoded_letter_of_Gabriel_Luetz_d_Aramon_after_1546_with_partial_deciphering.jpg</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">internal</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Enlarge</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span>Enciphered letter from </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gabriel_de_Luetz_d%27Aramon">/wiki/Gabriel_de_Luetz_d%27Aramon</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Gabriel de Luetz d<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#39;</span>Aramon</a>"&gt;</span><span>Gabriel de Luetz d'Aramon</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Ambassador_to_the_Ottoman_Empire">/wiki/French_Ambassador_to_the_Ottoman_Empire</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">French Ambassador to the Ottoman Empire</a>"&gt;</span><span>French Ambassador to the Ottoman Empire</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, after 1546, with partial decipherment</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line129"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>Language letter frequencies may offer little help for some extended historical encryption techniques such as </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Substitution_cipher#Homophonic_substitution">/wiki/Substitution_cipher#Homophonic_substitution</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Substitution cipher</a>"&gt;</span><span>homophonic cipher</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> that tend to flatten the frequency distribution. For those ciphers, language letter group (or n-gram) frequencies may provide an attack.
<span id="line130"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>Essentially all ciphers remained vulnerable to cryptanalysis using the frequency analysis technique until the development of the </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polyalphabetic_cipher">/wiki/Polyalphabetic_cipher</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Polyalphabetic cipher</a>"&gt;</span><span>polyalphabetic cipher</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>. While it was known to Al-Kindi to some extent,</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-Kadi_25-1</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-Kadi-25">#cite_note-Kadi-25</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>25<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-26</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-26">#cite_note-26</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>26<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> it was first clearly described in the work of </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Qalqashandi">/wiki/Al-Qalqashandi</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Al-Qalqashandi</a>"&gt;</span><span>Al-Qalqashandi</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> (1355–1418), based on the earlier work of </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibn_al-Durayhim">/wiki/Ibn_al-Durayhim</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Ibn al-Durayhim</a>"&gt;</span><span>Ibn al-Durayhim</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> (1312–1359), describing a polyalphabetic cipher in which each plaintext letter is assigned more than one substitute.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-27</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-27">#cite_note-27</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>27<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> It was later also described by </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leon_Battista_Alberti">/wiki/Leon_Battista_Alberti</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Leon Battista Alberti</a>"&gt;</span><span>Leon Battista Alberti</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> around the year 1467, though there is some indication that  Alberti's method was to use different ciphers (i.e., substitution alphabets) for various parts of a message (perhaps for each successive plaintext letter at the limit). He also invented what was probably the first automatic </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alberti_Cipher_Disk">/wiki/Alberti_Cipher_Disk</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Alberti Cipher Disk</a>"&gt;</span><span>cipher device</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, a wheel which implemented a partial realization of his invention. In the </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vigen%C3%A8re_cipher">/wiki/Vigen%C3%A8re_cipher</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Vigenère cipher</a>"&gt;</span><span>Vigenère cipher</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, a polyalphabetic cipher, encryption uses a </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">i</span>&gt;</span><span>key word</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">i</span>&gt;</span><span>, which controls letter substitution depending on which letter of the key word is used. In the mid-19th century </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Babbage">/wiki/Charles_Babbage</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Charles Babbage</a>"&gt;</span><span>Charles Babbage</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> showed that the Vigenère cipher was vulnerable to </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kasiski_examination">/wiki/Kasiski_examination</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Kasiski examination</a>"&gt;</span><span>Kasiski examination</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, but this was first published about ten years later by </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Kasiski">/wiki/Friedrich_Kasiski</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Friedrich Kasiski</a>"&gt;</span><span>Friedrich Kasiski</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-28</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-28">#cite_note-28</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>28<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line131"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>Although frequency analysis can be a powerful and general technique against many ciphers, encryption has still often been effective in practice, as many a would-be cryptanalyst was unaware of the technique. Breaking a message without using frequency analysis essentially required knowledge of the cipher used and perhaps of the key involved, thus making espionage, bribery, burglary, defection, etc., more attractive approaches to the cryptanalytically uninformed. It was finally explicitly recognized in the 19th century that secrecy of a cipher's algorithm is not a sensible nor practical safeguard of message security; in fact, it was further realized that any adequate cryptographic scheme (including ciphers) should remain secure even if the adversary fully understands the cipher algorithm itself. Security of the key used should alone be sufficient for a good cipher to maintain confidentiality under an attack. This fundamental principle was first explicitly stated in 1883 by </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auguste_Kerckhoffs">/wiki/Auguste_Kerckhoffs</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Auguste Kerckhoffs</a>"&gt;</span><span>Auguste Kerckhoffs</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> and is generally called </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerckhoffs%27s_Principle">/wiki/Kerckhoffs%27s_Principle</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Kerckhoffs<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#39;</span>s Principle</a>"&gt;</span><span>Kerckhoffs's Principle</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>; alternatively and more bluntly, it was restated by </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claude_Shannon">/wiki/Claude_Shannon</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Claude Shannon</a>"&gt;</span><span>Claude Shannon</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, the inventor of </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_theory">/wiki/Information_theory</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Information theory</a>"&gt;</span><span>information theory</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> and the fundamentals of theoretical cryptography, as </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">i</span>&gt;</span><span>Shannon's Maxim</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">i</span>&gt;</span><span>—'the enemy knows the system'.
<span id="line132"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>Different physical devices and aids have been used to assist with ciphers. One of the earliest may have been the scytale of </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greece">/wiki/Ancient_Greece</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Ancient Greece</a>"&gt;</span><span>ancient Greece</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, a rod supposedly used by the Spartans as an aid for a transposition cipher. In medieval times, other aids were invented such as the </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grille_(cryptography)">/wiki/Grille_(cryptography)</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Grille (cryptography)</a>"&gt;</span><span>cipher grille</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, which was also used for a kind of steganography. With the invention of polyalphabetic ciphers came more sophisticated aids such as Alberti's own </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cipher_disk">/wiki/Cipher_disk</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Cipher disk</a>"&gt;</span><span>cipher disk</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johannes_Trithemius">/wiki/Johannes_Trithemius</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Johannes Trithemius</a>"&gt;</span><span>Johannes Trithemius</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>' </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tabula_recta">/wiki/Tabula_recta</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Tabula recta</a>"&gt;</span><span>tabula recta</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> scheme, and </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson">/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Thomas Jefferson</a>"&gt;</span><span>Thomas Jefferson</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>'s </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson_disk">/wiki/Jefferson_disk</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Jefferson disk</a>"&gt;</span><span>wheel cypher</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> (not publicly known, and reinvented independently by </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bazeries">/wiki/Bazeries</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Bazeries</a>"&gt;</span><span>Bazeries</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> around 1900). Many mechanical encryption/decryption devices were invented early in the 20th century, and several patented, among them </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotor_machine">/wiki/Rotor_machine</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Rotor machine</a>"&gt;</span><span>rotor machines</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>—famously including the </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enigma_machine">/wiki/Enigma_machine</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Enigma machine</a>"&gt;</span><span>Enigma machine</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> used by the German government and military from the late 1920s and during </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II">/wiki/World_War_II</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">World War II</a>"&gt;</span><span>World War II</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-29</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-29">#cite_note-29</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>29<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> The ciphers implemented by better quality examples of these machine designs brought about a substantial increase in cryptanalytic difficulty after WWI.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-30</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-30">#cite_note-30</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>30<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line133"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line134"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">h3</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">span</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-headline</a>" <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Computer_era</a>"&gt;</span><span>Computer era</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">span</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">h3</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line135"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>Prior to the early 20th century, cryptography was mainly concerned with </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language">/wiki/Language</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Language</a>"&gt;</span><span>linguistic</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> and </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexicographic_code">/wiki/Lexicographic_code</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Lexicographic code</a>"&gt;</span><span>lexicographic</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> patterns. Since then the emphasis has shifted, and cryptography now makes extensive use of mathematics, including aspects of </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_theory">/wiki/Information_theory</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Information theory</a>"&gt;</span><span>information theory</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_complexity_theory">/wiki/Computational_complexity_theory</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Computational complexity theory</a>"&gt;</span><span>computational complexity</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistics">/wiki/Statistics</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Statistics</a>"&gt;</span><span>statistics</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combinatorics">/wiki/Combinatorics</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Combinatorics</a>"&gt;</span><span>combinatorics</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_algebra">/wiki/Abstract_algebra</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Abstract algebra</a>"&gt;</span><span>abstract algebra</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Number_theory">/wiki/Number_theory</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Number theory</a>"&gt;</span><span>number theory</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, and finite mathematics generally. Cryptography is also a branch of </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Engineering">/wiki/Engineering</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Engineering</a>"&gt;</span><span>engineering</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, but an unusual one since it deals with active, intelligent, and malevolent opposition; other kinds of engineering (e.g., civil or chemical engineering) need deal only with neutral natural forces. There is also active research examining the relationship between cryptographic problems and </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_physics">/wiki/Quantum_physics</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Quantum physics</a>"&gt;</span><span>quantum physics</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>.
<span id="line136"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>Just as the development of digital computers and electronics helped in cryptanalysis, it made possible much more complex ciphers. Furthermore, computers allowed for the encryption of any kind of data representable in any binary format, unlike classical ciphers which only encrypted written language texts; this was new and significant. Computer use has thus supplanted linguistic cryptography, both for cipher design and cryptanalysis. Many computer ciphers can be characterized by their operation on </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_numeral_system">/wiki/Binary_numeral_system</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Binary numeral system</a>"&gt;</span><span>binary</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bit">/wiki/Bit</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Bit</a>"&gt;</span><span>bit</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> sequences (sometimes in groups or blocks), unlike classical and mechanical schemes, which generally manipulate traditional characters (i.e., letters and digits) directly. However, computers have also assisted cryptanalysis, which has compensated to some extent for increased cipher complexity. Nonetheless, good modern ciphers have stayed ahead of cryptanalysis; it is typically the case that use of a quality cipher is very efficient (i.e., fast and requiring few resources, such as memory or CPU capability), while breaking it requires an effort many orders of magnitude larger, and vastly larger than that required for any classical cipher, making cryptanalysis so inefficient and impractical as to be effectively impossible.
<span id="line137"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line138"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">h3</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">span</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-headline</a>" <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Advent_of_modern_cryptography</a>"&gt;</span><span>Advent of modern cryptography</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">span</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">h3</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line139"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptanalysis">/wiki/Cryptanalysis</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Cryptanalysis</a>"&gt;</span><span>Cryptanalysis</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> of the new mechanical devices proved to be both difficult and laborious. In the United Kingdom, cryptanalytic efforts at </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bletchley_Park">/wiki/Bletchley_Park</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Bletchley Park</a>"&gt;</span><span>Bletchley Park</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> during WWII spurred the development of more efficient means for carrying out repetitious tasks. This culminated in the development of the </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colossus_computer">/wiki/Colossus_computer</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Colossus computer</a>"&gt;</span><span>Colossus</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, the world's first fully electronic, digital, </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_programming">/wiki/Computer_programming</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Computer programming</a>"&gt;</span><span>programmable</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> computer, which assisted in the decryption of ciphers generated by the German Army's </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lorenz_SZ40/42">/wiki/Lorenz_SZ40/42</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Lorenz SZ40/42</a>"&gt;</span><span>Lorenz SZ40/42</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> machine.
<span id="line140"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>Extensive open academic research into cryptography is relatively recent; it began only in the mid-1970s. In recent times, IBM personnel designed the algorithm that became the Federal (i.e., US) </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_Encryption_Standard">/wiki/Data_Encryption_Standard</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Data Encryption Standard</a>"&gt;</span><span>Data Encryption Standard</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>; </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whitfield_Diffie">/wiki/Whitfield_Diffie</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Whitfield Diffie</a>"&gt;</span><span>Whitfield Diffie</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> and </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Hellman">/wiki/Martin_Hellman</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Martin Hellman</a>"&gt;</span><span>Martin Hellman</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> published </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffie-Hellman">/wiki/Diffie-Hellman</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Diffie-Hellman</a>"&gt;</span><span>their key agreement algorithm</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>;</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-dh2_31-0</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-dh2-31">#cite_note-dh2-31</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>31<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> and the </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSA_(algorithm)">/wiki/RSA_(algorithm)</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">RSA (algorithm)</a>"&gt;</span><span>RSA</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> algorithm was published in </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Gardner">/wiki/Martin_Gardner</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Martin Gardner</a>"&gt;</span><span>Martin Gardner</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>'s </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">i</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_American">/wiki/Scientific_American</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Scientific American</a>"&gt;</span><span>Scientific American</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">i</span>&gt;</span><span> column. Following their work in 1976, it became popular to consider cryptography systems based on mathematical problems that are easy to state but have been found difficult to solve.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-32</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-32">#cite_note-32</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>32<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> Since then, cryptography has become a widely used tool in communications, </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_network">/wiki/Computer_network</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Computer network</a>"&gt;</span><span>computer networks</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, and </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_security">/wiki/Computer_security</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Computer security</a>"&gt;</span><span>computer security</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> generally. Some modern cryptographic techniques can only keep their keys secret if certain mathematical problems are </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_complexity_theory#Intractability">/wiki/Computational_complexity_theory#Intractability</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Computational complexity theory</a>"&gt;</span><span>intractable</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, such as the </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_factorization">/wiki/Integer_factorization</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Integer factorization</a>"&gt;</span><span>integer factorization</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> or the </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_logarithm">/wiki/Discrete_logarithm</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Discrete logarithm</a>"&gt;</span><span>discrete logarithm</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> problems, so there are deep connections with </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_mathematics">/wiki/Abstract_mathematics</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Abstract mathematics</a>"&gt;</span><span>abstract mathematics</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>. There are very few cryptosystems that are proven to be unconditionally secure. The </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-time_pad">/wiki/One-time_pad</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">One-time pad</a>"&gt;</span><span>one-time pad</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> is one, and was proven to be so by Claude Shannon. There are a few important algorithms that have been proven secure under certain assumptions. For example, the infeasibility of factoring extremely large integers is the basis for believing that </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSA_(cryptosystem)">/wiki/RSA_(cryptosystem)</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">RSA (cryptosystem)</a>"&gt;</span><span>RSA</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> is secure, and some other systems, but even so proof of unbreakability is unavailable since the underlying mathematical problem remains open. In practice, these are widely used, and are believed unbreakable in practice by most competent observers.  There are systems similar to RSA, such as one by </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_O._Rabin">/wiki/Michael_O._Rabin</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Michael O. Rabin</a>"&gt;</span><span>Michael O. Rabin</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> that are provably secure provided factoring  </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">i</span>&gt;</span><span>n = pq</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">i</span>&gt;</span><span> is impossible;  it is quite unusable in practice. The </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_logarithm_problem">/wiki/Discrete_logarithm_problem</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Discrete logarithm problem</a>"&gt;</span><span>discrete logarithm problem</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> is the basis for believing some other cryptosystems are secure, and again, there are related, less practical systems that are provably secure relative to the solvability or insolvability discrete log problem.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-33</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-33">#cite_note-33</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>33<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line141"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>As well as being aware of cryptographic history, cryptographic algorithm and system designers must also sensibly consider probable future developments while working on their designs. For instance, continuous improvements in computer processing power have increased the scope of </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brute-force_attack">/wiki/Brute-force_attack</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Brute-force attack</a>"&gt;</span><span>brute-force attacks</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, so when specifying </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Key_length">/wiki/Key_length</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Key length</a>"&gt;</span><span>key lengths</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, the required key lengths are similarly advancing.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-fortify_34-0</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-fortify-34">#cite_note-fortify-34</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>34<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> The potential effects of </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computing">/wiki/Quantum_computing</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Quantum computing</a>"&gt;</span><span>quantum computing</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> are already being considered by some cryptographic system designers developing </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-quantum_cryptography">/wiki/Post-quantum_cryptography</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Post-quantum cryptography</a>"&gt;</span><span>post-quantum cryptography</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>; the announced imminence of small implementations of these machines may be making the need for preemptive caution rather more than merely speculative.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-hac_4-1</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-hac-4">#cite_note-hac-4</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>4<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line142"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line143"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">h2</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">span</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-headline</a>" <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Modern_cryptography</a>"&gt;</span><span>Modern cryptography</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">span</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">h2</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line144"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">h3</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">span</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-headline</a>" <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Symmetric-key_cryptography</a>"&gt;</span><span>Symmetric-key cryptography</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">span</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">h3</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line145"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">role</span>="<a class="attribute-value">note</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">hatnote navigation-not-searchable</a>"&gt;</span><span>Main article: </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric-key_algorithm">/wiki/Symmetric-key_algorithm</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Symmetric-key algorithm</a>"&gt;</span><span>Symmetric-key algorithm</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line146"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">thumb class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span>Symmetric-key cryptography, where a single key is used for encryption and decryption</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line147"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>Symmetric-key cryptography refers to encryption methods in which both the sender and receiver share the same key (or, less commonly, in which their keys are different, but related in an easily computable way). This was the only kind of encryption publicly known until June 1976.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-dh2_31-1</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-dh2-31">#cite_note-dh2-31</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>31<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line148"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line149"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">thumb tright</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">thumbinner</a>" <span class="attribute-value" <span class="attribute-name">data-file-width</span>="<a class="attribute-value">632</a>" <span class="attribute-name">data-file-height</span>="<a class="attribute-value">660</a>" <span>/</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>  </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">thumbcaption</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">magnify</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:International_Data_Encryption_Algorithm_InfoBox_Diagram.svg">/wiki/File:International_Data_Encryption_Algorithm_InfoBox_Diagram.svg</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">internal</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Enlarge</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span>One round (out of 8.5) of the </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Data_Encryption_Algorithm">/wiki/International_Data_Encryption_Algorithm</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">International Data Encryption Algorithm</a>"&gt;</span><span>IDEA</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> cipher, used in most versions of </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pretty_Good_Privacy">/wiki/Pretty_Good_Privacy</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Pretty Good Privacy</a>"&gt;</span><span>PGP</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> and OpenPGP compatible software for time-efficient encryption of messages</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line150"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>Symmetric key ciphers are implemented as either </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Block_ciphers">/wiki/Block_ciphers</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Block ciphers</a>"&gt;</span><span>block ciphers</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> or </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stream_ciphers">/wiki/Stream_ciphers</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Stream ciphers</a>"&gt;</span><span>stream ciphers</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>. A block cipher enciphers input in blocks of plaintext as opposed to individual characters, the input form used by a stream cipher.
<span id="line151"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>The </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_Encryption_Standard">/wiki/Data_Encryption_Standard</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Data Encryption Standard</a>"&gt;</span><span>Data Encryption Standard</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> (DES) and the </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Encryption_Standard">/wiki/Advanced_Encryption_Standard</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Advanced Encryption Standard</a>"&gt;</span><span>Advanced Encryption Standard</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> (AES) are block cipher designs that have been designated </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography_standards">/wiki/Cryptography_standards</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Cryptography standards</a>"&gt;</span><span>cryptography standards</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> by the US government (though DES's designation was finally withdrawn after the AES was adopted).</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-aes_35-0</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-aes-35">#cite_note-aes-35</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>35<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> Despite its deprecation as an official standard, DES (especially its still-approved and much more secure </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple-DES">/wiki/Triple-DES</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Triple-DES</a>"&gt;</span><span>triple-DES</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> variant) remains quite popular; it is used across a wide range of applications, from ATM encryption</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-atm_36-0</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-atm-36">#cite_note-atm-36</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>36<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> to </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-mail_privacy">/wiki/E-mail_privacy</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">E-mail privacy</a>"&gt;</span><span>e-mail privacy</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-opgp_37-0</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-opgp-37">#cite_note-opgp-37</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>37<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> and </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Shell">/wiki/Secure_Shell</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Secure Shell</a>"&gt;</span><span>secure remote access</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-ssh_38-0</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-ssh-38">#cite_note-ssh-38</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>38<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> Many other block ciphers have been designed and released, with considerable variation in quality. Many, even some designed by capable practitioners, have been thoroughly broken, such as </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FEAL">/wiki/FEAL</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">FEAL</a>"&gt;</span><span>FEAL</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-hac_4-2</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-hac-4">#cite_note-hac-4</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>4<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-schneierbook_39-0</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-schneierbook-39">#cite_note-schneierbook-39</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>39<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line152"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>Stream ciphers, in contrast to the 'block' type, create an arbitrarily long stream of key material, which is combined with the plaintext bit-by-bit or character-by-character, somewhat like the </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-time_pad">/wiki/One-time_pad</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">One-time pad</a>"&gt;</span><span>one-time pad</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>. In a stream cipher, the output stream is created based on a hidden internal state that changes as the cipher operates. That internal state is initially set up using the secret key material. </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RC4">/wiki/RC4</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">RC4</a>"&gt;</span><span>RC4</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> is a widely used stream cipher.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-hac_4-3</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-hac-4">#cite_note-hac-4</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>4<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> Block ciphers can be used as stream ciphers.
<span id="line153"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptographic_hash_functions">/wiki/Cryptographic_hash_functions</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Cryptographic hash functions</a>"&gt;</span><span>Cryptographic hash functions</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> are a third type of cryptographic algorithm. They take a message of any length as input, and output a short, fixed length </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash_function">/wiki/Hash_function</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Hash function</a>"&gt;</span><span>hash</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, which can be used in (for example) a digital signature. For good hash functions, an attacker cannot find two messages that produce the same hash. </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MD4">/wiki/MD4</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">MD4</a>"&gt;</span><span>MD4</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> is a long-used hash function that is now broken; </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MD5">/wiki/MD5</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">MD5</a>"&gt;</span><span>MD5</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, a strengthened variant of MD4, is also widely used but broken in practice. The US </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Security_Agency">/wiki/National_Security_Agency</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">National Security Agency</a>"&gt;</span><span>National Security Agency</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> developed the Secure Hash Algorithm series of MD5-like hash functions: SHA-0 was a flawed algorithm that the agency withdrew; </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SHA-1">/wiki/SHA-1</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">SHA-1</a>"&gt;</span><span>SHA-1</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> is widely deployed and more secure than MD5, but cryptanalysts have identified attacks against it; the </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SHA-2">/wiki/SHA-2</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">SHA-2</a>"&gt;</span><span>SHA-2</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> family improves on SHA-1, but is vulnerable to clashes as of 2011; and the US standards authority thought it "prudent" from a security perspective to develop a new standard to "significantly improve the robustness of </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Institute_of_Standards_and_Technology">/wiki/National_Institute_of_Standards_and_Technology</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">National Institute of Standards and Technology</a>"&gt;</span><span>NIST</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>'s overall hash algorithm toolkit."</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-40</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-40">#cite_note-40</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>40<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> Thus, a </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NIST_hash_function_competition">/wiki/NIST_hash_function_competition</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">NIST hash function competition</a>"&gt;</span><span>hash function design competition</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> was meant to select a new U.S. national standard, to be called </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SHA-3">/wiki/SHA-3</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">SHA-3</a>"&gt;</span><span>SHA-3</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, by 2012. The competition ended on October 2, 2012 when the NIST announced that </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keccak">/wiki/Keccak</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Keccak</a>"&gt;</span><span>Keccak</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> would be the new SHA-3 hash algorithm.</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-41</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-41">#cite_note-41</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>41<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> Unlike block and stream ciphers that are invertible, cryptographic hash functions produce a hashed output that cannot be used to retrieve the original input data. Cryptographic hash functions are used to verify the authenticity of data retrieved from an untrusted source or to add a layer of security.
<span id="line154"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_authentication_code">/wiki/Message_authentication_code</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Message authentication code</a>"&gt;</span><span>Message authentication codes</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span> (MACs) are much like cryptographic hash functions, except that a secret key can be used to authenticate the hash value upon receipt;</span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">sup</span> <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">cite_ref-hac_4-4</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">reference</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography#cite_note-hac-4">#cite_note-hac-4</a>"&gt;</span><span><span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#91;</span>4<span class="entity"><span>&amp;</span>#93;</span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">sup</span>&gt;</span><span> this additional complication blocks an attack scheme against bare </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Md5">/wiki/Md5</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-redirect</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Md5</a>"&gt;</span><span>digest algorithms</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span>, and so has been thought worth the effort.
<span id="line155"></span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">p</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line156"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">h3</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">span</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">mw-headline</a>" <span class="attribute-name">id</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Public-key_cryptography</a>"&gt;</span><span>Public-key cryptography</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">span</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">h3</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line157"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">role</span>="<a class="attribute-value">note</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">hatnote navigation-not-searchable</a>"&gt;</span><span>Main article: </span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">a</span> <span class="attribute-name">href</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-key_cryptography">/wiki/Public-key_cryptography</a>" <span class="attribute-name">title</span>="<a class="attribute-value">Public-key cryptography</a>"&gt;</span><span>Public-key cryptography</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line158"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">thumb tright</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">thumbinner</a>" <span class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Public_key_encryption.svg">/wiki/File:Public_key_encryption.svg</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">image</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">img</span> <span class="attribute-name">alt</span>="<a class="attribute-value">diagram of Public-key cryptography showing public key and private key</a>" <span class="attribute-name">src</span>="<a class="attribute-value" href="view-source:https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Public_key_encryption.svg/250px-Public_key_encryption.svg.png">//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Public_key_encryption.svg/250px-Public_key_encryption.svg.png</a>" <span class="attribute-name">decoding</span>="<a class="attribute-value">async</a>" <span class="attribute-name">width</span>="<a class="attribute-value">250</a>" <span href="view-source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Public_key_encryption.svg">/wiki/File:Public_key_encryption.svg</a>" <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="end-tag">a</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span>Public-key cryptography, where different keys are used for encryption and decryption.</span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;/<span class="end-tag">div</span>&gt;</span><span>
<span id="line159"></span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">thumb tright</a>"&gt;</span><span></span><span>&lt;<span class="start-tag">div</span> <span class="attribute-name">class</span>="<a class="attribute-value">thumbinner</a>" <span
